content:
Nice clash, but a bit confusing around the leading zeros and the test case "50" is not good for this confusion.

The first bit is confusing:
"1. Take any four-digit number (leading zeros are allowed)"

'Leading zeros are allowed' makes it sound like they will be provided, but what you mean is the clasher has to add leading zeros to the input if it's not 4 digits.

Unfortunately I got 100% on tests and only 75% on validators because I assumed the inputs were provided with leading zeros. Test case "50" was not great for this because it still gives the same answer via two different paths if you make this mistake. (Doing "50 - 5 = 45" on the first turn instead of "5000 - 5 = 4995"):
n=4995 s=["0", "0", "0", "5"]
n=5355 s=["4", "5", "9", "9"]
n=1998 s=["3", "5", "5", "5"]
n=8082 s=["1", "8", "9", "9"]
n=8532 s=["0", "2", "8", "8"]
n=6174 s=["2", "3", "5", "8"]
Answer: 6

n=0045 s=["0", "5"]
n=5355 s=["0", "0", "4", "5"]
n=1998 s=["3", "5", "5", "5"]
n=8082 s=["1", "8", "9", "9"]
n=8532 s=["0", "2", "8", "8"]
n=6174 s=["2", "3", "5", "8"]
Answer: 6

I think you should add another test/validator pair that doesn't have this issue. 76 is one example that would have failed for my code, 84 or 385 also fail.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice, But, you copied a little bit from someone's contribution
I would remove leading zeroes check thought. It is long enough without it
I like the problem, but this is a complete duplicate of https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/16758d8d571cc067b5dc5df6c95d68de33cf

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle.
different description and test scenarios, so it is not "complete" duplicate
